title.value: Learning Silicon Dopant Transitions in Graphene using Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy
title.justification: This is the title of the paper.
title.quote:
Learning Silicon Dopant Transitions in
Graphene using Scanning Transmission
Electron Microscopy

extractions.description: This research introduces a data-centric machine learning method for predicting the transition dynamics of silicon atoms in a graphene lattice under the influence of an electron beam from a scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM). The method trains a neural network on collected STEM data to predict transition probabilities, which can be used to automate the control of silicon atom positions in the lattice.

type.justification: The paper presents empirical analyses to demonstrate the efficacy of the proposed machine learning method.
type.quote: We present empirical analyses that demonstrate the efficacy and generality of our approach.

name.justification: The paper focuses on the manipulation of silicon atoms in graphene, which falls under the domain of Material Science.
name.quote:
Our methodology relies on real data collected with a STEM device, so it is important that
the data gathered is informative for the task at hand.

name.justification: The paper discusses image processing and alignment techniques used to process STEM images, which are topics within Computer Vision.
name.quote:
In the bottom-left panel of Figure 3 we display one of the raw images captured with the
STEM device, and to the right of it the processed output.

name.justification: The paper presents a machine learning approach to predict transition probabilities of silicon atoms in graphene.
name.quote:
In this paper we present a technique for estimating these atomic transition dynamics using
machine learning techniques on collected observations.

name.justification: The paper uses convolutional neural networks for atomic alignment and noise reduction.
name.quote:
Our final, most robust solution was to use a denoising convolutional neural network to
solve the alignment problem directly from scans of the system.

is_contributed.justification: The paper utilizes existing convolutional neural networks for its methodology.
is_contributed.quote:
Our final, most robust solution was to use a denoising convolutional neural network to
solve the alignment problem directly from scans of the system.

is_executed.justification: The neural network models were executed as part of the experimental methodology.
is_executed.quote: We trained drift correction prediction with mean squared error.

is_compared.justification: The paper does not compare the neural network models to other models, but focuses on their application to the problem.
is_compared.quote: Note that the estimation of d_n is a denoising task.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper does not reference another paper specifically for the neural network model used.

name.justification: The paper generates synthetic datasets to test the learning behavior and scaling performance of the model.
name.quote: We generated a dataset of synthetic trajectories, each consisting of sequential image observations of a doped graphene system under random, correlated drift.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper does not reference another paper for the synthetic dataset used.

name.justification: The methodology relies on real data collected using a STEM device.
name.quote: To demonstrate the practical validity of our approach, we use our learned transition probabilities to automate the sequential control of a silicon atom on graphene towards a pre-specified target position.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper describes the methodology for collecting STEM data but does not reference another paper specifically for this dataset.

name.justification: The paper mentions using a Python API to control the STEM device.
name.quote: We used a Nion UltraSTEM 100, which grants us access to nearly every microscope control via a Python API.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper does not reference another paper specifically for the Python API used.
